fullSentence: Ἡροδότου Ἁλικαρνησσέος ἱστορίης ἀπόδεξις ἥδε, ὡς μήτε τὰ γενόμενα ἐξ ἀνθρώπων τῷ χρόνῳ ἐξίτηλα γένηται, μήτε ἔργα μεγάλα τε καὶ θωμαστά, τὰ μὲν Ἕλλησι τὰ δὲ βαρβάροισι ἀποδεχθέντα, ἀκλεᾶ γένηται, τά τε ἄλλα καὶ διʼ ἣν αἰτίην ἐπολέμησαν ἀλλήλοισι.
translation: This is the display of the inquiry of Herodotos of Halikarnassos, so that the deeds of men not be forgotten with time, and that great and marvelous deeds, some by the Hellenes and some by the barbarians, not lose their glory, including the reason why they waged war on each other.

content.author: Herodotos
content.background: Herodotos introduces himself and what he sets out to do. The word ἱστορίης has lived on in most modern European languages as 'history', and for many, his work stands as the first known historical text. On a personal note, much of what he wrote remains among my favorite texts in Ancient Greek. His *histories* are the most important source when dealing with the Persian Wars.

randomSteps.title: μήτε ... μήτε — Structure
randomSteps.text: This sentence uses the correlative structure 'μήτε ... μήτε' to link two ideas in a negative coordination. This kind of structure is common in Greek to express:.
randomSteps.question: What is the function of 'μήτε ... μήτε' in the phrase 'μήτε τὰ γενόμενα ... μήτε ἔργα μεγάλα τε καὶ θωμαστά';
options: They express a temporal sequence of events.
They introduce a pair of positive alternatives.
They are coordinating negatives meaning 'neither ... nor'.
They indicate contrast like 'but ... yet'.
They mark a cause and effect relationship.
They highlight a conditional clause ('if ... then').
randomSteps.answer: They are coordinating negatives meaning 'neither ... nor'.
randomSteps.noteOnCorrect: μήτε ... μήτε links two negated ideas, meaning 'neither this nor that'. It’s a key structure for expressing negative correlation in Greek.

randomSteps.question: What was Herodotos’ main purpose in writing his Histories?
options: To entertain readers with stories
To document the laws of Athens
To preserve great deeds and explain the causes of war
To glorify the Persian Empire
randomSteps.answer: To preserve great deeds and explain the causes of war

randomSteps.title: μὲν ... δὲ — Structure
randomSteps.text: The sentence uses the classic Greek balancing structure μὲν ... δὲ, often left untranslated in English but close to:
randomSteps.question: How would you best translate the μὲν ... δὲ construction?
options: On the one hand ... on the other hand
First ... then
Although ... nevertheless
Before ... after
Since ... but also
Great ... lesser
randomSteps.answer: On the one hand ... on the other hand
randomSteps.noteOnCorrect: Although it's often best rendered as 'on the one hand ... on the other', μὲν is frequently left untranslated because English marks contrast differently — through punctuation or emphasis.

randomSteps.question: Apart from the amazing stories (and fantasies) put forward by Herodotos why is his work so important?
options: Many of his fanciful stories are actually true
It is often our only ancient source that treats both Greeks and non-Greeks.
He put forward the scientific method and source criticism still in use in modern historic writing.
Otherwise we would never have heard of Halikarnassos.
randomSteps.answer: It is often our only ancient source that treats both Greeks and non-Greeks.

finalStep.instruction: Which best captures the purpose and tone of the sentence?
options: Herodotos wrote this to glorify Greece.
This is a record of wonders, legends, and myth from Greek history.
Herodotos introduces his inquiry into the causes and deeds of war by Greeks and non-Greeks.
Herodotos wants to tell the story of the great temple at Halikarnassos
finalStep.answer: Herodotos introduces his inquiry into the causes and deeds of war by Greeks and non-Greeks.

contextNote.text: Herodotos is often called the 'Father of History'. This sentence comes from the very first line of his *Histories* and sets the stage for a journey into the Greco-Persian wars and their causes.

fullSentence: νικῶντες δὲ τὸ μὲν τετραμμένον τῶν βαρβάρων φεύγειν ἔων, τοῖσι δὲ τὸ μέσον ῥήξασι αὐτῶν συναγαγόντες τὰ κέρεα ἀμφότερα ἐμάχοντο, καὶ ἐνίκων Ἀθηναῖοι. φεύγουσι δὲ τοῖσι Πέρσῃσι εἵποντο κόπτοντες, ἐς ὃ ἐς τὴν θάλασσαν ἀπικόμενοι πῦρ τε αἴτεον καὶ ἐπελαμβάνοντο τῶν νεῶν.
translation: In victory they let the routed foreigners flee, and brought the wings together to fight those who had broken through the center. The Athenians prevailed, then followed the fleeing Persians and struck them down. When they reached the sea they demanded fire and laid hold of the Persian ships.

content.author: Herodotos
content.background: Herodotos gives a dynamic account of the Battle of Marathon. The Athenian phalanx won the day on the wings - rooting the Persians. This pivotal battle marks the first major victory of the Greeks against Persia.

randomSteps.question: Why was the Battle of Marathon such a psychological victory for the Greeks?
options: It was the first time the Persians had been defeated in open battle.
The Greeks recovered the body of Leonidas.
The Athenians fought without their allies.
It was a naval battle showing Greek ship superiority.
randomSteps.answer: It was the first time the Persians had been defeated in open battle.

randomSteps.title: Athenian Tactics — Join the Wings!
randomSteps.text: The Athenians let part of the enemy flee but regrouped to attack the Persian center. The verbs here use participles to show how actions unfold together in Greek.
randomSteps.question: What is the main function of all these participles (like νικῶντες, κόπτοντες, συναγαγόντες)?
options: They express simultaneous or background actions
They show commands
They are used for comparison
They modify nouns like adjectives
They replace main verbs
randomSteps.answer: They express simultaneous or background actions

randomSteps.question: What was the main difference in equipment between Persian foot soldiers and Greek soldiers?
options: The Persians were usually outnumbered and therefor heavily armed, while the Greeks fought in lighter armour.
Greeks fought as hoplite citizen soldiers with heavy bronze armor while the Persians preferred mounted combat and light (ranged) troops.
Because Greeks fought naked the Persians were so shocked as to not be able to resist them.
Persian soldiers were slaves while Greeks were free soldiers.
randomSteps.answer: Greeks fought as hoplite citizen soldiers with heavy bronze armor while the Persians preferred mounted combat and light (ranged) troops.

finalStep.instruction: Which best captures the meaning of the sentence?
options: The Athenians chased the Persians into the mountains.
The Persians pretended to flee and ambushed the Athenians.
The Athenians encircled the Persians and set fire to their ships.
The Athenians fled but then regrouped at the coast.
finalStep.answer: The Athenians encircled the Persians and set fire to their ships.

contextNote.text: This passage captures the final moments of the Battle of Marathon — a defining victory for the Athenians. It shows both strategy and brutality, as the retreating Persians are cut down all the way to their ships.

fullSentence: ἡ δὲ στρατηλασίη ἡ βασιλέος οὔνομα μὲν εἶχε ὡς ἐπʼ Ἀθήνας ἐλαύνει, κατίετο δὲ ἐς πᾶσαν τὴν Ἑλλάδα
translation: The campaign of the king was said to be headed to Athens, but in fact it descended upon all of Greece.

content.author: Herodotos
content.background: Herodotos describes Xerxes’ campaign: it was said to be headed to Athens, but in truth, it descended upon all of Greece. A case of imperial ambition.

randomSteps.title: μὲν ... δὲ — Structure
randomSteps.text: The sentence uses the classic Greek balancing structure μὲν ... δὲ, often left untranslated in English but close to:.
randomSteps.question: How would you best translate the μὲν ... δὲ structure?
options: On the one hand ... on the other hand
At first ... eventually
First ... then
Although ... however
Since ... but also
Great ... lesser
randomSteps.answer: On the one hand ... on the other hand
randomSteps.noteOnCorrect: Even though 'on the one hand ... on the other' is probably the easiest way to remember this, μὲν is often left untranslated. In English, contrast is usually shown by word order or tone — so it's more about *function* than literal words.

finalStep.instruction: Which is the most accurate (abbreviated) translation of the sentence?
options: The campaign of the king went to Athens.
The king's army was named after Athens.
The campaign seemed headed to Athens but actually descended on all of Greece.
The king went secretly to Greece while naming Athens.
finalStep.answer: The campaign seemed headed to Athens but actually descended on all of Greece.

contextNote.text: The campaign of the king sparked much debate in Greece. While many city-states chose to fight, Thebes sided with Persia. Alexander the Great later destroyed it in retaliation.

fullSentence: Ἰάνων γὰρ ἀπηύρα, Ἰάνων ναύφρακτος Ἄρης ἑτεραλκὴς νυχίαν πλάκα κερσάμενος δυσδαίμονά τʼ ἀκτάν.
translation: Yes, for the Ionian naval force, turning the tide of battle, swept them away—ravaging the dark sea and the ill-fated shore.

content.author: Aeschylus
content.background: Xerxes, now returned to Susa, mourns the devastation of his fleet at Salamis. In this lament, he acknowledges the crushing defeat inflicted by the Ionian (Greek) navy, whose reversal of the tide sealed Persia’s fate.

randomSteps.instruction: Match the Greek words with their meanings.

randomSteps.title: War as a Force
randomSteps.text: The phrase 'ναύφρακτος Ἄρης' personifies Ares as fighting through ships — a poetic way to describe naval warfare.
randomSteps.question: What does this kind of phrase suggest about war in Greek tragedy?
options: It is unpredictable and divine in nature.
It is always fought by gods, not men.
It never involves ships or the sea.
It was seen as sacred and holy.
randomSteps.answer: It is unpredictable and divine in nature.
randomSteps.noteOnCorrect: Greek tragedy often shows war as being driven by gods or fate, with humans caught in the tide.

randomSteps.question: What is the form of 'ἀπηύρα'?
options: Aorist indicative active — 3rd singular
Imperfect middle — 3rd plural
Future indicative active — 3rd singular
Present subjunctive — 1st singular
randomSteps.noteOnCorrect: ἀπηύρα is the 3rd singular aorist of ἀπαυράω, 'to take away, sweep off'.

randomSteps.question: What makes Aeschylus’ *Persians* unusual among Greek tragedies?
options: It is set in the future.
It has no Chorus.
It depicts historical events from the enemy's perspective.
It was written in Persia.
randomSteps.answer: It depicts historical events from the enemy's perspective.
randomSteps.noteOnCorrect: Aeschylus’ *Persians* is the only surviving tragedy that centers on recent history and gives voice to the defeated Persians.

contextNote.text: This line brings us to the heart of Susa, not on the map of battles, but at the emotional epicenter of Persian loss. Aeschylus invites us to see war not only through the victors' eyes, but through the grief of the defeated.
